marketNews.title: One of Indonesia's Largest Nickel Smelters Reported Near Total Shutdown
marketNews.content:
Bloomberg reported that PT Gunbuster Nickel Industry – one of the largest nickel smelters in Indonesia – has cut production and is almost completely shut down. The news emerged only a few months after its Chinese parent, Jiangsu Delong Nickel Industry Co., went bankrupt. Jiangsu Delong Nickel Industry is the third-largest stainless-steel producer in China. Bloomberg said PT Gunbuster Nickel Industry has delayed payments to local energy suppliers and cannot obtain nickel ore, and has shut almost all production lines since early 2025. Bloomberg noted that PT Gunbuster Nickel Industry has a total nickel pig iron (NPI) production capacity of 1.8 million tonnes per year. In addition, Jiangsu Delong Nickel Industry also owns other nickel smelters and stainless-steel plants in Indonesia, such as PT Virtue Dragon Nickel Industry and PT Obsidian Stainless Steel. A Reuters report from July 2024 said that a key factor behind Jiangsu Delong’s bankruptcy was the deteriorating performance of its Indonesian joint venture due to lower ferronickel prices and higher material costs at the end of 2023. The same Reuters report also said that some industry players expect the Chinese operations to be partially taken over by Chinese state-owned enterprises. CRU Group analyst Kevin Bai told Reuters that a company the size of Jiangsu Delong is “too big to fail” and that bankruptcy reorganisation is not new in China.

Key Takeaway
The production cut at PT Gunbuster Nickel Industry could reduce Indonesia’s nickel pig iron supply, potentially pushing global nickel pig iron prices higher, given Indonesia’s status as the world’s largest nickel pig iron producer. PT Gunbuster’s smelter capacity represents roughly 20 % of Indonesia’s total nickel pig iron capacity of 9 million tonnes per year, based on 2022 data. Nickel pig iron prices have been gaining +4.5 % year-to-date.

On Friday (21 Feb), the stocks of nickel producers rose, with $NCKL up +7.26 % and $INCO up +4.45 %, while $MBMA rose +3.18 % to 390 IDR per share before closing flat.

marketNews.title: SMDR Enters Operator of Patimban Container Terminal and Related Corporate Actions
marketNews.content:
SMDR: Katadata reported that Samudera Indonesia, through its subsidiary PT Samudera Pelabuhan Indonesia, has completed the acquisition of new shares in PT Patimban Global Gateway Terminal – the container terminal operator at Patimban Port – for an undisclosed amount. The corporate action was carried out together with Africa Global Logistics SAS (AGL) and Toyota Tsusho Corporation (TTC), giving SMDR a 21 % stake in PT Patimban Global Gateway Terminal, while AGL and TTC hold 45 % and 34 % respectively. PT Patimban Global Terminal is slated to start commercial operations in 2026 and will operate the Patimban container terminal for 37 years. The terminal will be developed in phases to reach a target capacity of 3.7 million TEUs.

$TPIA: Chandra Asri Pacific disclosed in a clarification to the IDX that its infrastructure investment subsidiary PT Chandra Daya Investasi is exploring a possible IPO, although the plan remains under internal discussion and no timing has been set. The latest classification does not differ from the company’s August 2024 disclosure. The new clarification follows a Katadata report that TPIA plans to bring PT Chandra Daya Investasi to an IPO on the IDX before mid-2025.

$AMMN: Energy and Mineral Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said Amman Mineral International has not applied for an export-concession for copper concentrate. The comment came after AMMN, through its subsidiary PT Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara, sought a relaxation of copper concentrate export rules as the smelter commissioning proceeds slower than planned.

$KIJA: Jababeka Industrial Estate reported marketing sales of 3.19 trillion IDR in 2024 (+44 % YoY), surpassing the upgraded 2024 target of 3 trillion IDR. The result was driven by sales growth in Kendal (+73 % YoY), Cikarang (+3 % YoY) and Tanjung Lesung (+77 % YoY). KIJA targets marketing sales of 3.5 trillion IDR in 2025.

$SMIL: Sarana Mitra Luas CEO Hadi Suhermin bought approximately 67.9 million SMIL shares at an average price of 294 IDR per share on 19 Feb 2025, a total transaction value of about 20 billion IDR. After the transaction, Suhermin’s direct ownership rose from 49.31 % to 50.08 %.

$AKRA: AKR Corporindo controlling shareholder and President Director Soegiarto Adikoesoemo bought 916,000 AKRA shares at an average price of 1,115 IDR per share on 17 Feb 2025, a total of about 1 billion IDR. After the transaction, his direct ownership increased from 0.646 % to 0.651 %.

$MENN: Menn Teknologi Indonesia announced that six companies purchased 67 % of MENN’s shares – at an undisclosed price – from three directors and commissioners (Michael Halim Mulyanto, Edrick Pramana and Agus Mulyanto). The six buyers are PT Penajam Makmur Jaya, PT Negara Maju Makmur, PT Sarjana Sama Indah, PT Kalimantan Sejahtera Indonesia, PT Kalimantan Indah Kedepan, and PT Sarana Majemuk Indonesia. Following the transaction, the new shareholders will be required to make a mandatory tender offer for the remaining shares.

$PADI: PT Sentosa Bersama Mitra bought 650 million PADI shares at an average price of 15 IDR per share on 19 Feb 2025, a total of about 9.8 billion IDR, raising its ownership from zero to 5.75 %. In a separate transaction, shareholder MINA’s Eveline Listijosuputro sold roughly 204.8 million PADI shares at an average price of 15 IDR per share on 19 Feb 2025, a total of about 3.1 billion IDR, reducing her stake from 2.92 % to 1.81 %.

Students staged protests in Jakarta and several other cities on Thursday (20 Feb) against budget cuts in the Prabowo administration, fearing impacts on social protection, contract-worker jobs and scholarship withdrawals. The protests, dubbed “Indonesia Gelap” on social media, called on President Prabowo to review the free-meal program and cancel a budget cut of 306.7 trillion IDR. The protests continued on Friday (21 Feb) with participation from various civil-society coalitions.

Finance Minister Sri Mulyani said on Thursday (20 Feb) that the government plans to issue a jumbo bond to fund the construction of three million houses per year, without disclosing the amount. The proceeds will be used to expand the housing-finance liquidity facility (FLPP). At the same time, Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo said BI will buy the bonds in the secondary market. In December 2024, Warjiyo said the central bank would buy up to 150 trillion IDR of government bonds in the secondary market in 2025, with 100 trillion IDR earmarked for debt-switching with a burden-sharing scheme.

Senior Treasury Official Parjiono said on Thursday (20 Feb) that the government’s debt-to-GDP ratio rose to 39.36 % in 2024 (vs 39.21 % in 2023), while the revenue-to-GDP ratio fell to 12.84 % (vs 13.33 % in 2023). Existing regulations cap the debt ratio at 60 % of GDP. Deputy Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Ferry Irawan said the government is committed to fiscal stability, targeting a 2025 debt-to-GDP range of 37.82-38.71 %.

National Economic Council Chairman Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan told President Prabowo on Thursday (20 Feb) that he has proposed eliminating fuel subsidies in 2027 and replacing them with direct cash transfers. Earlier, Energy Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said in early January 2025 that a new fuel-subsidy distribution scheme would be announced soon. On Friday (21 Feb) Bahlil said the “blending” scheme – combining fuel-price subsidies with cash transfers – remains the most likely option for 2025, though no exact start date was given.

DPR member Eddy Soeparno said on Thursday (20 Jan) that the House will start discussing a revision of the Oil and Gas Law no later than April 2025. Investment Committee Chair of the Oil and Gas Companies Association Moshe Rizal criticised the recurring “urgent” label for the law, noting that internal government debates, not investor concerns, delay the amendment.

Agriculture Minister Andi Amran Sulaiman said the government will conduct a market operation to stabilise food prices ahead of Ramadan and Idul Fitri. The president has ordered that no staple food price exceed the maximum retail price (HET). National Food Agency head Arief Prasetyo Adi said the operation will run from 24 Feb 2025 to the end of March 2025, supported by the Indonesian Retailers Association, Charoen Pokphand Indonesia ($CPIN) and Japfa Comfeed Indonesia ($JPFA), and 452 food kiosks in 31 provinces and 102 regencies/cities.

Energy Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said on Friday (21 Feb) that the government has granted an export licence for copper concentrate to PT Freeport Indonesia until June 2025, the target date for completing the smelter repair in the JIIPE KEK, Gresik, after an October 2024 fire. The licence was granted on a force-majeure basis; if the repair is not completed by June 2025, the government will impose a maximum export tax.

The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) detained PDI-P Secretary-General Hasto Kristiyanto on Thursday (20 Feb) over alleged bribery for DPR member appointments and obstruction of the investigation. Following the arrest, PDI-P did not appoint a replacement, and party chairwoman Megawati Soekarnoputri will directly command the party, instructing regional heads to postpone the scheduled party retreat in Magelang (21-28 Feb 2025).

Nusantara Pelabuhan Handal (PORT) shareholder PT Episenta Utama Investasi bought about 26.7 million PORT shares at an average price of 818 IDR per share on 8 Jan 2025, a total of about 21.9 billion IDR, raising its stake from 23.2 % to 24.2 %.
